Introduction

Supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) is a broad classification term for tachycardias that originate proximal to the bundle branches and Purkinje fibers in the cardiac conduction system (

figure 1
); these arrhythmias may originate within the sinoatrial node, the atria, the atrioventricular (AV) node, or the His bundle.  In SVT, the ventricles are usually depolarized normally via the His-Purkinje system, typically resulting in narrow QRS complexes (ie, <120 msec) on ECG.

Pathophysiology and types of SVT



The classification of SVT is somewhat confusing and varies in different resources.  In general, tachyarrhythmias reflect a disorder of either impulse generation (eg, ectopic activity) or impulse propagation (eg, abnormal conduction circuit).  Using this framework, this article provides a conceptual approach based on the typical point of origin (

figure 2
) and electrophysiologic disturbances that characterize each type of SVT.  They are described in more detail in separate articles.

Sinus tachycardia



Sinus tachycardia results from rapid impulse generation in the sinoatrial node, usually driven by an increase in sympathetic tone.  The rapid impulse generation can be physiologic (eg, exercise) or in response to underlying pathology (eg, sepsis, pulmonary embolism).

Paroxysmal SVT



Paroxysmal SVT (PSVT) describes a subset of SVTs with a regular rhythm, rapid rate, and abrupt onset and offset.  The 2 most common types, which involve abnormal impulse propagation through electric circuits, include:



  • AV nodal reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT) results from the development of a small reentrant circuit involving dual conduction pathways within the AV node.
  • AV reentrant tachycardia (AVRT) is the characteristic arrhythmia of Wolff-Parkison-White syndrome.  It results from the development of a large reentrant circuit involving the AV node and an accessory conduction pathway that directly connects the atria to the ventricles.


Another PSVT is focal atrial tachycardia (ectopic pacemaker), which results from a small focus of electrical activity located in a portion of the atria outside the sinoatrial node.  Although atrial fibrillation and atrial flutter are SVTs that often occur paroxysmally, they have distinct clinical manifestations and are not included in the PSVT classification.

Atrial fibrillation



Atrial fibrillation results from disorganized and chaotic atrial activity that often originates in the pulmonary vein ostia of the left atrium.

Atrial flutter



Atrial flutter results from the development of a large reentrant circuit that usually involves the cavotricuspid isthmus of the right atrium.

Multifocal atrial tachycardia



Multifocal atrial tachycardia results from multiple sources of ectopic atrial activity outside the sinoatrial node.



For all these types of SVT (other than sinus tachycardia), the arrhythmia becomes the primary pacemaker for the atria (because impulse generation in the sinoatrial node is suppressed).



Other, less common arrhythmias (eg, junctional tachycardia) are also sometimes considered SVTs.

Clinical presentation



Patients with SVT may be asymptomatic or may have relatively mild symptoms, including palpitations or a feeling of a racing heart.  Other possible symptoms include:



  • Dyspnea
  • Chest discomfort, diaphoresis
  • Light-headedness
  • Syncope (rarely and only with very high ventricular rates)


On physical examination, radial artery palpation demonstrates a rapid pulse.  The rhythm can be regular or irregular, depending on the type of SVT.



ECG findings for each of these SVTs are described in the next section.  However, rapid SVTs can often be difficult to differentiate on ECG or cardiac monitoring because the rapid ventricular activity (ie, QRS complexes) can obscure the atrial activity.  Administering intravenous adenosine can help identify an undifferentiated rapid SVT (narrow-complex tachycardia).  By slowing or temporarily pausing conduction through the AV node, adenosine allows for visualization of P waves or other atrial activity and enables identification of the arrhythmia.

ECG findings

Sinus tachycardia



Sinus tachycardia (

figure 3
) demonstrates a rapid and regular rhythm with normal P waves preceding each QRS complex.  The atrial rate typically matches the ventricular rate and can range from 100/min to up to 180/min at rest.

AVNRT and AVRT



AVNRT (

figure 4
) and AVRT (
figure 5
) demonstrate rapid and regular QRS complexes.  The atria undergo retrograde depolarization either simultaneously with the ventricles or just after the ventricles, resulting in inverted P waves buried (not visible) in the QRS complex (more characteristic of AVNRT) or visible P waves just after the QRS complex (more characteristic of AVRT).  The ventricular rate can range from approximately 140-220/min.

Focal atrial tachycardia



Focal atrial tachycardia demonstrates a rapid and regular rhythm with abnormally shaped P waves preceding each QRS complex (similar to sinus tachycardia but with altered P wave morphology).

Atrial fibrillation



Atrial fibrillation (

figure 6
) demonstrates no organized P waves, but fibrillation waves may be visible.  QRS complexes occur at random intervals (irregularly irregular R-R intervals) due to random conduction of the chaotic atrial activity through the AV node to the ventricles.  The atrial rate is typically 500-600/min.  With rapid ventricular response, the ventricular rate can range from 100-200/min.

Atrial flutter



Atrial flutter (

figure 7
) demonstrates characteristic flutter waves representative of the atrial activity.  The ventricular response rate can be variable or constant (R-R intervals can be irregular or can appear regular).  The atrial rate is usually approximately 300/min.  When the ventricular response rate is constant, the ventricular rate is a factor of approximately 300 (eg, ~150/min with 2:1 conduction, ~100/min with 3:1 conduction).

Multifocal atrial tachycardia



Multifocal atrial tachycardia (

figure 8
) demonstrates P waves with â‰¥3 different morphologies.  The irregular atrial activity creates irregular ventricular activity (irregular R-R intervals).  The atrial rate typically matches the ventricular rate and can range from 100/min to approximately 150/min.

Management



The initial management of SVT generally follows the narrow QRS complex portion of the adult tachycardia algorithm (

figure 9
), with intravenous adenosine used when needed to assist in the identification of an undifferentiated SVT.  Rarely, SVT demonstrates wide QRS complexes (eg, atrial fibrillation with bundle branch block, preexcited atrial fibrillation).



Additional management of SVT is specific to the type of arrhythmia and is further discussed in the dedicated articles for each arrhythmia.

Complications



  • SVT with a very high ventricular rate creates a risk for hemodynamic collapse due to impaired diastolic filling and can lead to sudden cardiac arrest.
  • SVT that is sustained for a prolonged period (eg, several weeks or more) creates a risk for tachycardia-induced cardiomyopathy.

Prognosis



The prognosis of SVT is highly variable and depends primarily on the type of arrhythmia and the clinical condition that may have precipitated it.  Prompt management of SVT is crucial to minimizing morbidity and mortality.

Summary



Supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) is a broad classification term for tachycardias that originate proximal to the bundle branches and Purkinje fibers in the cardiac conduction system.  Types of SVT include sinus tachycardia, paroxysmal SVT (eg, atrioventricular nodal reentrant tachycardia, atrioventricular reentrant tachycardia, focal atrial tachycardia), atrial fibrillation, atrial flutter, and multifocal atrial tachycardia.  SVTs usually have narrow QRS complexes on ECG, and, when rapid, it can be difficult to differentiate one from one another.  Intravenous adenosine allows for visualization of underlying atrial activity and can help in the diagnosis of an undifferentiated rapid SVT.
